encounters.notes: Started MTX therapy with folic acid supplementation
Good RA control on MTX 10 mg weekly; no MTX side effects

encounters.diagnosis: New essential hypertension; RA stable; plan MTX dose increase
encounters.notes: Elevated BP readings 145–155/90–95; MTX increased to 20mg

encounters.diagnosis: Stable RA; controlled HTN; mild CKD (stable)
encounters.notes: Overall well; RA controlled on MTX 20 mg; BP controlled
5 days nasal congestion, facial pain, headache, green discharge

encounters.diagnosis: Acute liver injury likely DILI and/or severe methotrexate toxicity
encounters.notes: Severe fatigue, jaundice, epigastric pain, confusion

adverseEvents.description: Acute hepatocellular injury with jaundice and encephalopathy following TMP-SMX initiation in patient on chronic MTX
Asterixis, disorientation to time/place, GCS 13 (E4 V3 M6)
ALT/AST >20× ULN, INR elevated, bilirubin ≥3× ULN with clinical jaundice
Synergistic hepatotoxicity with TMP-SMX; oral mucosal ulcerations present

rucam.title: RUCAM Scoring (Hepatocellular pattern)
rows: Time to onset (from drug start to injury)
TMP-SMX started Jun 15 → symptoms Jun 20 → presentation Jun 21 (≈6 days)
Compatible interval for idiosyncratic hepatocellular DILI (5–90 days).
TMP-SMX and MTX held on admission; recovery not yet documented but improvement expected
Early improvement expected; data incomplete at time of scoring.
Age >55 and ongoing alcohol use increase risk.
Viral hepatitis pending; no history/exposure; ultrasound ordered; no ischemic/septic event
Alternatives considered and largely excluded clinically.
Methotrexate and TMP-SMX both well-known for hepatotoxicity and interaction

ctcae.title: CTCAE Hepatic Toxicity Scoring
rows: Coagulopathy (± encephalopathy) consistent with acute liver failure.
ctcae.overall_grade: CTCAE Grade 4 — Life-threatening; requires urgent intervention

rucam_ctcae_analysis.reasoning: The patient developed acute jaundice, confusion, and hepatic tenderness shortly after initiating TMP-SMX (started June 15; symptoms June 20; presentation June 21), a timeline that strongly fits idiosyncratic hepatocellular DILI. There is low likelihood of alternative causes—no fever or hemodynamic instability to suggest ischemic or septic hepatitis, viral panels are pending with low pretest probability, and there is no autoimmune or metabolic history. Mechanistically, TMP-SMX can raise free methotrexate levels and impair folate metabolism; in an older patient with alcohol use (and possible CKD), this pharmacologic interaction plausibly potentiates hepatocellular necrosis and explains concurrent mucosal/CNS findings. The clinical pattern is hepatocellular (expected ALT > AST ≫ ALP) and the presence of encephalopathy with presumed INR >1.5 and elevated bilirubin meets criteria for non-acetaminophen acute liver failure. RUCAM totals 7 (Probable), with TMP-SMX as the primary culprit and methotrexate as a significant co-factor. Immediate management includes withdrawal of both agents, initiation of N-acetylcysteine, aggressive supportive care, and ICU-level monitoring.

assessment.impression: Acute liver injury likely DILI and/or severe methotrexate toxicity
differential: Severe methotrexate toxicity (± pancytopenia, hepatic/renal injury)
Acute decompensation of undiagnosed chronic liver disease

rucam_ctcae_analysis.reasoning: no autoimmune or metabolic history; no fever or hemodynamic instability

assessment.impression: Suboptimal control of T2DM/HTN, Chronic Fatigue Syndrome possibly related to MASLD.

encounter.chief_complaint: Increased fatigue over the past 4-5 months
encounter.hpi: Sarah Miller, a 43-year-old administrative assistant, presents with debilitating fatigue affecting work performance. She averages 6.5 hours of non-restorative sleep per night and experiences RA-related discomfort, particularly in the right wrist. She takes Ibuprofen 4-5 times per week for pain and chemically-induced frequent bloating.

physical_exam.msk: Mild effusion in right MCP joint 3, mild pain on movement.
physical_exam.other_systems: Vital Signs: BP 146/92 mmHg (sitting), HR 82 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.8°C, SpO₂ 99% on room air. Anthropometrics: Height 1.64 m, Weight 86 kg (BMI 32.0 kg/m²; class I obesity). Weight reported as broadly stable over the past 12 months. Skin/Sclera: Anicteric sclerae; no chronic liver disease stigmata. Abdomen: Soft, lax, normal liver span, no tenderness.

management.follow_up: Follow-up in 4 weeks to evaluate LFTs and MTX eligibility.

assessment.impression: Elevated ALT of 78 U/L, concerning for hepatocellular inflammation, potentially related to Metabolic Dysfunction-associated Steatotic Liver Disease (MASLD). Methotrexate initiation deferred pending further investigation.

encounter.chief_complaint: Review of abnormal liver function tests and planning for rheumatoid arthritis treatment.
encounter.hpi: Patient reports making small changes to diet and activity since the last visit, with an approximate 0.5–1 kg weight loss. The elevated ALT of 78 U/L was reviewed. Potential Metabolic Dysfunction-associated Steatotic Liver Disease (MASLD) was discussed as a contributing factor. Patient was educated on the significance of these results and the potential risk for liver injury if starting Methotrexate without further clearance.

physical_exam.general: Vital Signs: BP 142/90 mmHg (sitting), HR 80 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.7°C, SpO₂ 99% on room air. Anthropometrics: Weight 85.5 kg (BMI 31.8 kg/m²).

management.follow_up: Return for follow-up in 4 weeks to review investigation results. Continued monitoring and lifestyle modifications advised.

encounter.reason_for_visit: Review of abnormal liver function tests and planning for rheumatoid arthritis treatment.

assessment.impression: Follow-up regarding normalization of liver function tests and initiation of Methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis management. Normalization of LFTs with ALT at 35 U/L. Negative workup for chronic liver conditions. Likely transient elevation possibly related to MASLD. Cleared for Methotrexate initiation.

encounter.chief_complaint: Follow-up regarding normalization of liver function tests (LFTs) and potential initiation of Methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis management.
encounter.hpi: Since the previous review, Sarah reports increased adherence to dietary advice and gentle walking most days, noting a ~1.5 kg weight loss since March. Comprehensive hepatitis workup (viral, autoimmune, metabolic) returned negative. ALT has decreased to 35 U/L, suggesting transient elevation. Patient is considered low-risk for MTX initiation.

assessment.impression: Initiation of Methotrexate for Rheumatoid Arthritis management.

encounter.chief_complaint: Initiation of Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drug (DMARD) - Methotrexate (MTX) for Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) management.
encounter.hpi: Sarah Miller presents for the initiation of Methotrexate treatment for RA. She reports her joint pain has been stable but remains a significant source of discomfort, affecting her daily activities. A thorough review of her medical history, medication adherence, and lifestyle was conducted. The patient confirms receipt and comprehension of the Methotrexate informational leaflet, indicating understanding of the treatment regimen and potential adverse effects. The decision to commence Methotrexate was made following normalization of liver function tests (LFTs) as of May 6, 2024. The patient reiterated understanding of the importance of strict compliance with the monitoring schedule due to the severe hepatotoxicity risk associated with Methotrexate.

physical_exam.general: Vital Signs: BP 138/86 mmHg (sitting), HR 80 bpm, RR 15/min, Temp 36.7°C, SpO₂ 98% on room air. Anthropometrics: Weight 84 kg (BMI 31.2 kg/m²). Weight stable compared with early May.

labs: Full Blood Count (FBC) every six weeks

management.follow_up: First LFT/FBC evaluation scheduled for July 15, 2024. Regular monitoring every six weeks for the next 6 months. Patient to contact clinic immediately if severe nausea, vomiting, or jaundice occur.

encounter.reason_for_visit: Initiation of Methotrexate for Rheumatoid Arthritis management.

assessment.impression: Methotrexate-induced Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI) presenting with elevated ALT (185 U/L, 4.6x ULN), with new intermittent nausea and increased fatigue. Rheumatoid arthritis symptoms are improving on Methotrexate.

encounter.chief_complaint: Routine Methotrexate (MTX) monitoring. Reports of new intermittent nausea and increased fatigue.
encounter.hpi: Sarah Miller, a 43-year-old female, presents for routine Methotrexate monitoring. She reports ~1 kg unintentional weight loss over the past month, attributed to reduced appetite and intermittent nausea, primarily in the evenings. No vomiting or diarrhea. Fatigue levels have returned to pre-MTX initiation severity. Rheumatoid arthritis symptoms have significantly improved with diminished joint pain and increased daily function since starting Methotrexate. Recent labs show ALT elevated to 185 U/L (4.6x ULN).

physical_exam.general: Vital Signs: BP 144/92 mmHg (sitting), HR 88 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.8°C, SpO₂ 98% on room air.

labs: Repeat liver function tests in four weeks

management.follow_up: Follow up in four weeks. Advised to remain vigilant for any worsening of symptoms or new signs of liver dysfunction such as jaundice, further exacerbated fatigue, or darker urine. Ensure adherence to adjusted Methotrexate regimen. Attend Hepatology consultation.

encounter.reason_for_visit: Routine Methotrexate monitoring and management of new symptoms of nausea and fatigue, and elevated liver enzymes.

assessment.impression: Severe, Acute Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI) with developing cholestasis.

encounter.chief_complaint: Urgent review for new onset jaundice, dark urine, and constant, severe nausea leading to anorexia.
encounter.hpi: Patient presented with new onset jaundice, dark urine, and severe nausea leading to anorexia. Initial ED vital signs: BP 132/88 mmHg (sitting), HR 102 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 37.3°C, SpO₂ 97% on room air. Weight 81.5 kg (BMI 30.3 kg/m²). Patient reported significant weight loss of approximately 4.5 kg over the past 4–6 weeks due to nausea and anorexia. Jaundice noted upon waking, dark urine observed. Symptoms are severe and persistent. Laboratory analysis revealed significantly elevated ALT levels and bilirubin of 110 μmol/L, indicating severe cholestasis. INR was stable at 1.1.

imaging: USG Abdomen Complete - STAT (Accession Number: USG-240812-001). Report indicates severe MASH/MASLD, no mechanical obstruction. Impression: Severe hepatocellular DILI superimposed on advanced chronic liver disease (MASH).

management.follow_up: Close follow-up post-hospital discharge to reassess liver function and re-evaluate RA treatment plan, considering contraindication for future Methotrexate use.

encounter.reason_for_visit: New onset jaundice, dark urine, severe nausea, and anorexia, concerning for acute liver injury.

assessment.impression: Severe Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI) secondary to Methotrexate, with a RUCAM score of 9/10, indicating a high likelihood of causation. No features of Acute-on-Chronic Liver Failure (ACLF). Underlying Metabolic Associated Steatotic Hepatitis (MASH).

encounter.hpi: The patient is reviewed on Day 3 of her hospital admission following severe DILI. Methotrexate was stopped immediately upon recognizing it as the causative agent. Sarah remains significantly jaundiced; however, nausea has shown slight improvement since admission. Vital neurological signs include a stable Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15, with no evidence of hepatic encephalopathy (HE); absence of asterixis or cognitive impairment. The ALT level, though elevated at 420 U/L, is beginning to decline, suggesting a positive response to the cessation of Methotrexate. Crucially, the INR remains stable at 1.1, indicating preserved liver synthetic function. These clinical findings collectively confirm a diagnosis of severe, cholestatic DILI in a patient with underlying Metabolic Associated Steatotic Hepatitis (MASH), markedly susceptible to hepatotoxic insults.

physical_exam.general: Sarah exhibits pronounced jaundice, evidenced by a total bilirubin level of 190 μmol/L. Despite this, she appears alert and reports moderate comfort under current care measures. Vital Signs (ward review): BP 128/82 mmHg, HR 96 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 37.0°C, SpO₂ 97% on room air. Anthropometrics: Weight 81 kg (BMI 30.1 kg/m²). No significant interval weight change since admission.
physical_exam.other_systems: CNS Examination: She is fully oriented, demonstrating no neurological deficits. GCS remains a reassuring 15 with negative neurological signs including asterixis, tremor, and speech abnormalities. Cardio/Pulmonary: Vital signs are stable with no indications of fluid overload, pulmonary distress, or hepatorenal syndrome. Abdominal Examination: The abdomen is soft and non-tender. The liver edge is not easily palpable due to Sarah's body habitus, yet no tenderness is detected upon examination.

labs: Daily INR evaluations until ALT levels fall below 150 U/L

management.follow_up: Arrange a Fibroscan (Liver Stiffness Measurement) in three months to assess fibrosis arising from chronic MASH and the acute DILI event. Coordinate with Rheumatology for the initiation of a non-hepatotoxic DMARD alternative, such as Hydroxychloroquine or a biologic, to manage RA without compromising liver health.

encounter.reason_for_visit: Review on Day 3 of hospital admission following severe DILI.

description: Medilogik DMARD Safety Monitoring with Highlights

props.rawText:
**Medilogik**
**Task Group:** DMARD Safety Monitoring & Patient Engagement Workflow
**Created By:** Dr. P. Stevens, MD, MRCGP
**Date Created:** 2024-06-03
**Priority:** **High**
**Status:** Active
**Task ID:** **MTX_MONITOR_SM_01_RECUR**
**Associated Encounter:** Outpatient – Methotrexate Initiation Consultation

---

## **1. Task Description (Expanded)**

“Establish a comprehensive Methotrexate (MTX) monitoring workflow for Sarah Miller following initiation of 7.5 mg weekly MTX therapy for Rheumatoid Arthritis.
The objective is to ensure safe continuation of MTX, early detection of hepatotoxicity, cytopenias, or intolerance, and reinforcement of adherence to patient education and safety-netting protocols.”

---

# **2. Monitoring Schedule (Detailed)**

### **Initial Post-Initiation Assessment**

* **Due Date:** **2024-07-15**
* **Tests Required:**

  * Full Liver Function Panel (ALT, AST, ALP, GGT, Bilirubin, INR)
  * Full Blood Count (FBC)
* **Purpose:**

  * Assess early hepatic response to MTX
  * Detect early cytopenias
  * Evaluate need for dose adjustment or pause

---

### **Ongoing Routine Monitoring**

* **Frequency:** Every **6 weeks**
* **Duration:** First 6 months (June–December 2024)
* **Tests at each interval:**

  * **LFT**
  * **FBC**
  * **Renal Profile (U+E)**
  * **CRP (optional, if RA control uncertain)**

### **Post-6-Month Monitoring**

* If stable → move to **every 8–12 weeks** per DMARD safety protocol.

---

# **3. Medilogik Auto-Alert Configuration**

### **High-Priority Auto-Alerts (Immediate clinician notification)**

* **ALT > 2× ULN (>80 U/L)**
* **AST > 2× ULN**
* **Platelets < 150 ×10⁹/L**
* **Neutrophils <1.5 ×10⁹/L**
* **WBC <3.0 ×10⁹/L**
* **Bilirubin rising trend across two tests**

**Action Trigger:**
→ Display interruptive alert in Medilogik clinician inbox
→ Flag patient chart with **“DMARD Safety Alert – Review Required”**

---

### **Moderate-Priority Auto-Alerts**

* **Gradual ALT rise but < 2× ULN**
* **New macrocytosis**
* **eGFR decline**
  → Routed to GP monitoring pool for review within 72 hours.

---

# **4. Associated Patient Education Tasks**

### **Patient Education Pack Delivery**

* Includes:

  * MTX Information Leaflet (British Society for Rheumatology standard)
  * Liver toxicity symptoms sheet
  * Medication schedule card (MTX + folic acid)
* Marked as **Completed – Provided in clinic, 2024-06-03**

---

### **Compliance Check Call**

* **Scheduled:** 7 days post initiation (2024-06-10)
* **Purpose:**

  * Confirm correct dosing (once weekly only)
  * Verify folic acid timing
  * Screen for early side effects
* Responsible Team: GP Support / Clinical Pharmacist

---

### **Alcohol Intake Advisory**

* Task to review patient’s alcohol intake at each monitoring appointment
* Documented baseline: “Patient consumes 12 units/week”
* Goal: Reduce to < 6 units/week for MTX safety

---

# **5. Clinical Safety & Governance Notes**

* MTX initiation authorized based on:

  * ALT normalization (ALT 35)
  * Negative viral hepatitis screen
  * Negative autoimmune hepatitis screen
  * Normal synthetic liver profile
  * Low Fib-4 (0.9)

* MASLD acknowledged as background risk; enhanced vigilance maintained.

* MTX classified as a **high-risk drug**, requiring strict adherence to monitoring timeline.

* Medilogik will:

  * Log missed tests
  * Auto-generate overdue notices after 48 hours
  * Escalate persistent failures to GP clinical lead

---

# **6. Follow-Up & Tracking**

### **Next Steps**

* **Next scheduled test:** 2024-07-15
* **Next clinician review:** Early August appointment already booked
* **Rheumatology liaison:** If RA control insufficient at 12 weeks, Medilogik flags GP to consider rheumatology review

### **Dashboard Integration**

Medilogik integrates with the practice DMARD dashboard:

* Displays latest LFT/FBC trends
* Risk colour-coding (Green → Amber → Red)
* Task completion metrics

Sarah is currently classified as:
**Amber – New MTX Start (requires intensified monitoring)**

---

highlights.text: ALT > 2× ULN (>80 U/L)
AST > 2× ULN
Bilirubin rising trend across two tests
Gradual ALT rise but < 2× ULN
Patient consumes 12 units/week

* MTX initiation authorized based on:

  * ALT normalization (ALT 35)
Negative viral hepatitis screen
Negative autoimmune hepatitis screen
Normal synthetic liver profile
Low Fib-4 (0.9)
MASLD acknowledged as background risk; enhanced vigilance maintained.
* MTX classified as a **high-risk drug**, requiring strict adherence to monitoring timeline.

description: Viper MTX Safety Clearance with Highlights

props.rawText:
# **VIPER**

**Module:** Clinical Review & Planning Module
**Entry Type:** GP MTX Safety Clearance – Structured Review
**Author:** Dr. P. Stevens, MD, MRCGP
**Date:** 2024-05-06
**Linked Encounter:** Outpatient Review – Pre-DMARD Evaluation
**Source:** VIPER Clinical Decision Support Engine

---

### **V – Verification of Clinical Data**

* Reviewed full laboratory panel from 2024-05-06:

  * **ALT 35 U/L (normal)**
  * **AST 30 U/L (normal)**
  * **ALP 102 U/L (normal)**
  * **Bilirubin normal**
  * **INR normal**
* Reviewed all chronic hepatitis screening results:

  * **HBsAg negative, HBcAb negative, HCV Ab negative**
* Reviewed autoimmune screen:

  * **ANA negative, ASMA negative, LKM-1 negative, IgG normal**
* Reviewed metabolic panel:

  * **Ferritin normal, transferrin saturation normal, A1AT normal**
* Reviewed Fib-4 Index: **0.9 (low risk)**
* Confirmed no hepatotoxic concomitant medications apart from intermittent NSAID use, now minimised.

---

### **I – Interpretation of Risk**

* **All reversible causes of transaminitis previously present have resolved.**
* Hepatocellular injury noted in Encounter 1 is confirmed as **transient MASLD flare**, not chronic liver disease.
* Negative viral, autoimmune, and metabolic screen eliminates major contraindications to MTX.
* Current liver function is **stable and low-risk** for MTX initiation.
* MASLD remains a background risk factor, but risk is mitigated by:

  * recent weight-loss efforts
  * improved diet
  * reduced alcohol use
* Overall risk classification: **Low–Moderate**, acceptable for MTX with strict monitoring.

---

### **P – Planning**

* Approve **Methotrexate initiation at 7.5 mg once weekly**, start date **2024-06-03**.
* Prescribe **Folic Acid 5 mg weekly**, 24h post-dose.
* Implement a **strict 6-weekly LFT + FBC monitoring protocol**:

  * 1st scheduled test: **2024-07-15**
  * Auto-alerts configured for:

    * ALT > 2× ULN
    * Platelets < 150 × 10⁹/L
    * Neutrophils < 1.5 × 10⁹/L

---

### **E – Escalation & Safety Netting**

* Safety-net advice provided:

  * Stop MTX immediately and contact clinic if **jaundice, dark urine, severe fatigue, vomiting**, or RUQ pain develop.
  * Avoid NSAIDs unless absolutely required; paracetamol preferred.
  * Abstain from alcohol entirely during first 6 weeks.
* Discussed MASLD contribution and the need for ongoing lifestyle improvement.
* No current indication for hepatology referral.
* Escalation trigger: persistent ALT > 1.5× ULN at any follow-up.

---

### **R – Recommendations (Final VIPER Output)**

“Following full review of all laboratory, clinical, and risk-stratification data, the patient is **safe to commence Methotrexate** under a structured monitoring schedule. No evidence of chronic liver disease or absolute contraindication. Continue MASLD lifestyle management. LFTs must be followed rigorously every 6 weeks. Patient educated on red-flag symptoms and agrees to the plan.”

---

MASLD remains a background risk factor, but risk is mitigated by:

reduced alcohol use
* Overall risk classification: **Low–Moderate**, acceptable for MTX with strict monitoring.

* Auto-alerts configured for:

    * ALT > 2× ULN

Avoid NSAIDs unless absolutely required; paracetamol preferred.

Nervecentre Lab Alert with Highlighted Key Information

props.rawText:
### Nervecentre

**Module:** Laboratory Alerting & Task Management
**Event Type:** Automated Laboratory Alert – LFT Derangement 

---

#### 1. Alert Event Summary

* **System Alert ID:** NC-LFT-20240305-001
* **Patient:** Sarah Miller (MRN: SM43850603, DOB: 1981-06-03, Age 43, F) 
* **Linked Encounter:**

  * Visit Type: Outpatient – General Practice
  * Date & Time: 2024-03-05 @ 10:15:22 (GMT+01:00)
  * Clinician: Dr. P. Stevens, MD, MRCGP 
* **Ordering Provider:** Dr. P. Stevens
* **Requesting Location:** GP Clinic – Room 3

---

#### 2. Trigger Details

* **Trigger Rule:** Rule ID 4.2 – *ALT ≥ 1.5 × ULN*
* **Analyte:** Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT)
* **Result:** 78 U/L (ULN: 40 U/L; 1.95 × ULN) 
* **Associated LFTs at Time of Alert:** 

  * AST: 55 U/L (H, <35)
  * ALP: 105 U/L (N, 30–130)
  * Bilirubin (Total): 12 μmol/L (N, <21)
  * INR: 1.0 (N, 0.8–1.2)
  * Platelets: 250 × 10⁹/L (N, 150–400)
* **Pattern of Injury:** Hepatocellular (AST/ALT ratio ≈ 0.7; no cholestasis)
* **Alert Level:** Level 2 – Non-Critical, Mandatory Acknowledgment within 72 hours
* **Severity Banding (System):**

  * ALT 1.5–3 × ULN → *Moderate Elevation*
  * Bilirubin normal, INR normal → *No acute liver failure criteria*

---

#### 3. Distribution & Delivery Log

* **Primary Recipient:**

  * Dr. P. Stevens (Responsible GP / LFT Ordering Clinician)
* **Secondary Visibility:**

  * GP Practice LFT Review Pool (Monitoring queue, “GP-LFT-MONITOR”)
* **Delivery Channels:**

  * Nervecentre mobile app push notification to Dr. Stevens
  * Medilogik Inbox message (flagged ‘LFT abnormal – review required’)
  * Alert icon added to Sarah Miller’s digital chart (LFT flag)

**Delivery Timeline:**

1. **2024-03-05 10:17:02** – LFT panel verified in LIS; HL7 message received by Nervecentre.
2. **2024-03-05 10:17:10** – Rule ID 4.2 fired (ALT 78 U/L ≥ 1.5 × ULN).
3. **2024-03-05 10:17:15** – Level 2 alert created and queued.
4. **2024-03-05 10:17:20** – Push notification sent to Dr. Stevens’ device and Medilogik Inbox.
5. **2024-03-05 10:17:25** – Chart flag updated (amber LFT icon).

---

#### 4. Acknowledgment & Escalation Logic

* **Acknowledgment Requirement:**

  * Alert must be electronically acknowledged by the responsible clinician **within 72 hours** of creation.

* **Current Status:**

  * Acknowledgement: **Pending**
  * Last System Check: 2024-03-05 18:00 – *No user interaction recorded.*

* **Scheduled Reminders:**

  * **+24 hours (2024-03-06 10:17)** – In-app reminder to Dr. Stevens (planned).
  * **+48 hours (2024-03-07 10:17)** – Second reminder and addition to GP practice “Unacknowledged LFT” dashboard (planned).
  * **+72 hours (2024-03-08 10:17)** – If still unacknowledged, auto-escalate to:

    * GP Duty Doctor / Clinical Lead inbox
    * Practice admin queue: “Follow-up abnormal results – contact clinician”.

* **Escalation Rule:**

  * Rule ID 7.1 – *Unacknowledged Level 2 lab alert >72 h → escalate to on-call / clinical lead.*

---

#### 5. Linked Tasks (Automatic)

1. **Task ID:** NC-TASK-20240305-ALT-REVIEW

   * **Title:** Review abnormal LFT (ALT 78 U/L) and document plan.
   * **Owner:** Dr. P. Stevens
   * **Priority:** Medium
   * **Due Date/Time:** 2024-03-08 10:15 (72h from encounter)
   * **Completion Status:** Open
   * **Task Notes (Pre-populated):**

     * “ALT 78 U/L (~1.95 × ULN), hepatocellular pattern, no bilirubin or INR derangement. Consider MASLD, NSAID use, and DMARD candidacy (planned MTX). Document clinical correlation, repeat LFT interval, and DMARD decision.”

2. **Task ID:** NC-TASK-20240305-MASLD-COUNSEL

   * **Title:** Confirm lifestyle counselling & weight-loss plan for suspected MASLD.
   * **Owner:** GP Practice Nurse / Health Coach (Pool: ‘MASLD-COACH’)
   * **Priority:** Low
   * **Due Date/Time:** 2024-03-19 09:00
   * **Status:** Open

---

#### 6. Safety & Governance Notes

* **Protocol Reference:**

  * Local GP LFT Policy v3.1 – “Any ALT ≥ 1.5 × ULN requires documented review and repeat LFT within 3–6 months, sooner if planning hepatotoxic medication (e.g., Methotrexate).”
* **Clinical Risk Comment (System):**

  * Flag added: “Planned DMARD (MTX) – ensure LFT trend and chronic liver disease screen BEFORE initiation.”
* **Audit Trail (Extract):**

  * 2024-03-05 10:17 – Alert generated automatically (System).
  * 2024-03-05 10:17 – Delivery confirmed to device ‘STEVENS_GP_IPHONE’.
  * 2024-03-05 10:18 – Chart flag updated (System).
  * *No user acknowledgment recorded yet.*

highlights.text: Rule ID 4.2 – *ALT ≥ 1.5 × ULN*
**Result:** 78 U/L (ULN: 40 U/L; 1.95 × ULN)
Severity Banding (System):
ALT 1.5–3 × ULN → *Moderate Elevation*
Local GP LFT Policy v3.1 – “Any ALT ≥ 1.5 × ULN requires documented review and repeat LFT within 3–6 months, sooner if planning hepatotoxic medication (e.g., Methotrexate).”
Planned DMARD (MTX) – ensure LFT trend and chronic liver disease screen BEFORE initiation.”

description: Nervecentre Encounter 2 - Critical MTX Alert with Highlights

props.rawText:
### **Nervecentre**

**Module:** Laboratory Alerting & Medicines Safety
**Event Type:** *Critical Medicine-Related LFT Alert – Methotrexate Patient*

---

## **1. Alert Event Summary**

* **System Alert ID:** NC-LFT-20240814-003
* **Patient:** Sarah Miller (MRN: SM43850603, DOB: 1981-06-03, 43F)
* **Linked Encounter:**

  * Visit Type: Outpatient – Rheumatology Review
  * Date & Time: **2024-08-14 @ 14:32**
  * Clinician: **Dr. R. Hall (Rheumatology Registrar)**
* **Ordering Provider:** Dr. R. Hall
* **Requesting Location:** Rheumatology Clinic – Room 5

---

## **2. Trigger Details**

* **Trigger Rule:**

  * **Rule 4.5 – ALT ≥ 3 × ULN OR ALT ≥ 2 × ULN in patients on hepatotoxic drugs (MTX).**

* **Analyte Triggering Alert:**

  * **ALT: 158 U/L** (ULN 40 U/L → **3.95 × ULN**)

* **Associated LFTs:**

  * AST: 132 U/L (H)
  * ALP: 118 U/L (N)
  * Total Bilirubin: 17 μmol/L (N)
  * Direct Bilirubin: 4 μmol/L (N)
  * INR: 1.1 (N)
  * Platelets: 238 × 10⁹/L (N)

* **Pattern of Injury:**

  * **Hepatocellular**, ALT > AST > 3× ULN, normal bilirubin

* **Alert Level:** **Level 3 – *Critical hepatotoxicity (MTX patient)***

* **Severity Banding:**

  * MTX patient with ALT >3× ULN → **“Immediate clinical review required”**

* **Medication Linkage:**

  * Methotrexate 15mg weekly (started ~12 weeks prior)
  * Folic acid 5mg weekly

---

## **3. Distribution & Delivery Log**

**Primary Recipients:**

* Dr. R. Hall (Ordering clinician)
* Rheumatology Consultant On-Call
* GP (auto-copied for medicine safety review)

**Secondary Recipients:**

* Pharmacy / DMARD Safety Team (Queue: *DMARD-SAFETY-PRIORITY*)
* Nervecentre Medicines Safety Dashboard

**Delivery Channels:**

* Nervecentre mobile push
* Desktop inbox message
* Email notification to Rheumatology duty mailbox (policy-mandated for Level 3 alerts)

**Delivery Timeline:**

1. **2024-08-14 14:33:10** – LFTs verified by lab
2. **2024-08-14 14:33:16** – Rule 4.5 fired (ALT 158)
3. **2024-08-14 14:33:20** – High-priority alert created
4. **2024-08-14 14:33:25** – Push & desktop alerts sent to Rheumatology
5. **2024-08-14 14:33:28** – Medicines Safety Dashboard updated (red flag)

Current status: **Alert acknowledged by Dr. Hall at 14:41**
Escalation aborted (acknowledged in time)

---

## **4. Acknowledgment & Escalation Logic**

* **Acknowledgement Requirement:**

  * Level 3 alerts require action **within 2 hours**.

* **Acknowledgement Status:**

  * **Acknowledged – Dr. Hall at 14:41**
  * Comment: “MTX held. Repeat LFTs in 48h. Arrange fibrosis screen & ultrasound.”

* **Escalation Path (not triggered):**

  * Rheumatology Consultant (15 min delay)
  * Duty Manager (if >2h unacknowledged)
  * Pharmacy DMARD team (parallel escalation)

---

## **5. Linked Tasks (Automatic)**

### **1. NC-TASK-20240814-MTX-HOLD**

* **Title:** “Suspend Methotrexate pending repeat LFTs”
* **Owner:** Dr. R. Hall
* **Due:** Immediate
* **Status:** **Completed (14:42)**
* **Notes:** MTX paused; patient notified.

---

### **2. NC-TASK-20240814-LFT-REPEAT48H**

* **Title:** “Repeat LFT panel in 48 hours (MTX hepatotoxicity)”
* **Owner:** Phlebotomy Hub (*Priority*)
* **Due:** 2024-08-16 @ 09:00
* **Status:** Open

---

### **3. NC-TASK-20240814-CLD-SCREEN**

* **Title:** “Non-invasive liver disease screen (MASLD, viral, autoimmune)”
* **Owner:** GP Practice (Liver Screening Queue)
* **Due:** 2024-08-21
* **Status:** Open

---

## **6. Safety & Governance Notes**

* **Policy Applied:**

  * NHS DMARD Safety Monitoring – “Stop MTX if ALT > 3× ULN.”
  * Local Hepatotoxicity Protocol v5.2

* **System Safety Comments:**

  * “High probability of MTX-related transaminitis; ensure follow-up imaging & screen.”
  * “No synthetic dysfunction (INR normal). No bilirubin rise. No acute liver failure features.”

* **Audit Trail (Extract):**

  * 14:33 – Alert created
  * 14:33 – Notifications dispatched
  * 14:41 – Acknowledged (Hall_R)
  * 14:42 – Action documented: MTX held

---

## **7. Impact on Medicines Dashboard**

* MTX moved to “**Withheld – Abnormal LFT**”
* Next review set: **2024-08-16 (await repeat LFTs)**
* Risk Score updated → **High**

description: Nervecentre Encounter 3 - Critical Inpatient Alert with Highlights

props.rawText:
### **Nervecentre**

**Module:** Laboratory Alerting, Inpatient Monitoring & Early Warning Scores
**Event Type:** *Critical LFT Alert + AMU Deterioration Observation Trigger*
**Location:** Acute Medical Unit (AMU) – Bed 12

---

## **1. Alert Event Summary**

* **System Alert ID:** NC-LFT-20240902-009

* **Patient:** **Sarah Miller** (MRN: SM43850603, 43F)

* **Linked Encounter:**

  * Admission Type: **Emergency – Medical**
  * Date & Time: **2024-09-02 @ 18:22**
  * Admitting Clinician: **Dr. K. Hussain (AMU SHO)**
  * Responsible Consultant: **Dr. A. Bennett (Gastroenterology)**

* **Clinical Presentation:**

  * Nausea, reduced appetite, right upper quadrant discomfort
  * Recent MTX cessation after abnormal LFTs
  * Query **Methotrexate-related DILI vs MASLD flare**

---

## **2. Trigger Details – Critical LFT Alarm**

### **Primary Trigger Rule:**

* **Rule 4.7 – ALT ≥ 5 × ULN OR significant rise since last test.**
* **ALT: 242 U/L** (ULN 40 → **6.05 × ULN**)
* **AST: 198 U/L (H)**
* **ALP: 130 U/L (upper-normal)**
* **GGT: 165 U/L (H)**
* **Total Bilirubin: 26 μmol/L (mild elevation)**
* **Direct Bilirubin: 8 μmol/L**
* **INR: 1.2 (upper-normal, no synthetic failure)**
* **Albumin: 39 g/L (normal)**
* **Platelets: 212 × 10⁹/L**

### **Pattern of Injury:**

* **Marked hepatocellular injury**
* Mild bilirubin elevation (not cholestatic)
* No acute liver failure criteria

### **Severity Level:**

* **Level 4 – Critical Alert (Inpatient)**
* Requires **review within 30 minutes**

### **Medication Linkage:**

* MTX stopped 2 weeks ago
* Patient on **prednisolone 10 mg** for RA flare
* PRN paracetamol (flagged for dosing review)

---

## **3. Early Warning Score (NEWS2) Trigger**

* **NEWS2 Score:** **4** (Yellow)

  * HR 108
  * RR 20
  * Temp 37.8°C
  * SpO₂ 98% RA
  * BP 122/78
* Trigger: “**Physiological change + abnormal blood tests → senior review required**”

### **Observation Alert ID:** NC-OBS-20240902-04

Delivered simultaneously with the LFT alert.

---

## **4. Distribution & Delivery Log**

**Primary Recipients:**

* Dr. Hussain (Admitting SHO)
* AMU Registrar (Dr. Maxwell)
* Gastroenterology On-Call Team
* Medicines Safety Team (due to previous MTX exposure)

**Secondary Recipients:**

* AMU Nurse in Charge
* EWS (NEWS2) Monitoring Dashboard
* Liver Pathway Tracker

### **Delivery Timeline**

1. **18:24:50** – LFTs verified
2. **18:24:55** – Rule 4.7 fired (ALT 242)
3. **18:25:00** – Critical alert sent (Level 4)
4. **18:25:05** – NEWS2 trigger elevated to “Urgent Review”
5. **18:25:10** – On-call Gastroenterology bleeped automatically
6. **18:27:14** – Acknowledged by **Dr. Hussain (AMU SHO)**
7. **18:33:22** – Registrar review documented (Maxwell_J)

---

## **5. Acknowledgment & Escalation Logic**

* **Required Acknowledgement:** Within **30 min**
* **Status:**

  * **Acknowledged – On time (Dr. Hussain @ 18:27)**

### **Escalation process (auto-triggered but closed):**

* **Stage 1 – SHO (5 min)** → Completed
* **Stage 2 – Registrar (15 min)** → Completed
* **Stage 3 – Gastro Consultant (manual if worsening)** → Not required

### **Registrar Safety Note:**

“Likely MTX-related hepatocellular injury, improving bilirubin. Keep NBM for abdominal US, order hepatitis serologies, and trend LFTs q12h.”

---

## **6. Linked Inpatient Tasks (Automatic)**

### **1. NC-TASK-20240902-LFTQ12**

* **Title:** “Repeat LFT + INR every 12 hours”
* **Owner:** AMU Nursing & Phlebotomy
* **Due:** First repeat at **06:00 (03-Sept)**
* **Status:** Open

---

### **2. NC-TASK-20240902-US-LIVER**

* **Title:** “Arrange urgent liver ultrasound”
* **Owner:** Radiology – Priority Queue
* **Due:** Within 24h
* **Status:** Open
* **Notes:** NBM from midnight.

---

### **3. NC-TASK-20240902-VIRAL-AUTOIMMUNE-SCREEN**

* **Title:** “Complete full non-invasive liver screen (viral, autoimmune, metabolic)”
* **Owner:** AMU SHO
* **Due:** 2024-09-03 @ 14:00
* **Status:** Open
* **Pre-populated Notes:**

  * HBV surface antigen
  * HCV Ab
  * ANA, ASMA, AMA
  * Ferritin, transferrin saturation
  * Coeliac serology

---

### **4. NC-TASK-20240902-DILI-REVIEW**

* **Title:** “Consultant Gastro review for suspected DILI”
* **Owner:** Dr. Bennett
* **Due:** Same day (post-ward round)
* **Status:** Pending Consultant signature

---

## **7. Safety & Governance Notes**

* **Policies Applied:**

  * Acute Liver Injury Protocol v4.0
  * DMARD Monitoring (MTX section)
  * NEWS2 Escalation Framework
  * Risk of DILI – high if ALT > 5× ULN

* **System Warnings:**

  * “Recent MTX exposure – evaluate for DILI.”
  * “Trend LFTs closely; risk of progression without synthetic failure yet.”
  * “Investigate MASLD overlap given BMI and T2DM.”

* **Audit Trail (Extract):**

  * 18:25 – Alert created
  * 18:25 – Gastro team notified
  * 18:27 – SHO acknowledgment
  * 18:33 – Registrar review documented
  * 18:34 – LFT-trend monitoring scheduled

---

## **8. Inpatient Liver Monitoring Dashboard Update**

* **Status:** HIGH RISK – Hepatocellular injury
* **Next data refresh:** 12-hourly
* **Outstanding items:**

  * Ultrasound
  * Viral/autoimmune screen
  * Consultant review
  * LFT trend check

description: ICE Pre-DMARD Screening Orders with Highlights

props.rawText:
**ICE**
**Order Set:** *Comprehensive Chronic Hepatitis & Hepatic Fitness Screening (Pre-DMARD Initiation)*
**Ordering Clinician:** Dr. P. Stevens, MD, MRCGP
**Date:** 2024-04-01
**Location:** GP Outpatient Clinic
**Indication:** *Abnormal ALT (78 U/L) and pre-Methotrexate screening*
**Urgency:** Routine (Non-urgent, but required before treatment)
**Associated Diagnosis Code:** SNOMED CT – *Rheumatoid arthritis (69896004)* + *Transaminitis (197315008)*

---

## **1. Viral Hepatitis Serology Panel**

**Tests Ordered:**

* HBsAg – Hepatitis B Surface Antigen
* Anti-HBc Total – Hepatitis B Core Antibody
* Anti-HCV – Hepatitis C Antibody
* HEV IgG – Hepatitis E Antibody (IgG)

**Priority:** Routine
**Turnaround:** 48–72 hours
**Specimen:** Serum (Gold top)

**Extended Laboratory Note for Technologists:**
“Pre-DMARD safety testing. Patient requires clearance prior to potential MTX initiation.
Please ensure reflex testing for HBV DNA if:

* HBsAg positive OR
* Isolated anti-HBc positivity.
  This result determines antiviral prophylaxis requirements before DMARDs.”

**Clinical Rationale:**
“Full viral exclusion is mandatory. Even occult HBV could lead to reactivation under MTX. HCV/HEV exclusion required to avoid missed chronic inflammation.”

---

## **2. Autoimmune Hepatitis Screening Panel**

**Tests Ordered:**

* ANA with reflex titre
* ASMA (Anti-Smooth Muscle Antibody)
* LKM-1 (Liver-Kidney Microsomal Antibody)
* Total IgG

**Priority:** Routine
**Turnaround:** 5–7 days
**Specimen:** Serum

**Extended Note:**
“If ANA positive, perform reflex titre and pattern ID.
If IgG > upper limit, flag result for consultant pathologist review.”

**Clinical Rationale:**
“Rule out autoimmune hepatitis. Active AIH is an absolute contraindication to starting MTX. MTX may worsen hepatic autoimmune inflammation.”

---

## **3. Metabolic Liver Screen**

**Tests Ordered:**

* Serum Ferritin
* TIBC (Total Iron-Binding Capacity)
* Transferrin Saturation (%)
* Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Level

**Priority:** Routine
**Turnaround:** 48 hours
**Specimen:** Serum

**Extended Note:**
“Ferritin >300 or transferrin saturation >45% should reflex to HFE genetic typing.
Low A1AT level should reflex to phenotype typing if available.”

**Clinical Rationale:**
“Exclude haemochromatosis and A1AT deficiency—both amplify DILI risk and are critical to identify before MTX.”

---

## **4. Repeat Liver Function Panel (Scheduled)**

**Tests Ordered:**

* ALT
* AST
* ALP
* GGT
* Bilirubin (Total & Direct)
* INR
* Albumin
* Platelets (FBC add-on)
* R-Factor auto-calculation

**Priority:** Deferred / Scheduled for 4 weeks
**Target Date:** 2024-05-01
**Turnaround:** Same day
**Specimen:** Serum + Coag tube

**Extended Note:**
“Trend assessment required. If ALT remains above 1.5× ULN, do not proceed with MTX.
If ALT normalizes, clear for low-dose MTX initiation.
ICE to generate automatic reminder 3 days before due date.”

**Clinical Rationale:**
“To confirm normalization of hepatic inflammation and determine hepatic fitness prior to hepatotoxic DMARD therapy.”

---

## **ICE System Flags Applied**

* **Safety Flag:** “MTX Pre-Check Required – Do Not Initiate Until Results Reviewed.”
* **Auto-Alert:** Notify ordering clinician if results show:

  * HBsAg positive
  * ALT > 2× ULN
  * IgG significantly elevated
  * Positive autoimmune markers
* **Patient Status Flag:** “Recurrent MASLD flare – monitor trends.”

---

## **Specimen Collection Instructions**

* Fasting NOT required
* Advise patient to avoid NSAIDs 48h prior to blood draw
* Document alcohol intake in the last 72 hours
* Ensure same-day processing for INR

---

highlights.text: Abnormal ALT (78 U/L) and pre-Methotrexate screening
HBsAg – Hepatitis B Surface Antigen
Anti-HBc Total – Hepatitis B Core Antibody
Anti-HCV – Hepatitis C Antibody
HEV IgG – Hepatitis E Antibody (IgG)

HBV DNA if:

* HBsAg positive OR
* Isolated anti-HBc positivity.
Even occult HBV could lead to reactivation under MTX.
Rule out autoimmune hepatitis.
Active AIH is an absolute contraindication to starting MTX.
MTX may worsen hepatic autoimmune inflammation.
Exclude haemochromatosis and A1AT deficiency—both amplify DILI risk and are critical to identify before MTX.
If ALT remains above 1.5× ULN, do not proceed with MTX.
To confirm normalization of hepatic inflammation and determine hepatic fitness prior to hepatotoxic DMARD therapy.

ALT > 2× ULN

Advise patient to avoid NSAIDs 48h prior to blood draw

description: ICE Acute DILI Emergency Orders with Highlights

props.rawText:
**ICE**
**Order Set:** *Acute Liver Injury Diagnostic & Management Pathway (ED Rapid Evaluation Protocol)*
**Ordering Clinician:** Dr. P. Stevens
**Date:** 2024-08-12
**Location:** ED – Rapid Assessment Bay
**Indication:** *Severe Acute Hepatocellular DILI with bilirubin >100 μmol/L, ALT 490 U/L*
**Priority:** **STAT / Emergency**
**Linked Diagnosis Codes:**

* *Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI) — SNOMED CT: 240517000*
* *Acute Jaundice — 43959009*
* *Cholestasis — 14140009*

---

# **1. Acute Liver Function & Synthetic Function Panel (STAT)**

**Tests Ordered:**

* ALT
* AST
* ALP
* GGT
* Total Bilirubin
* Direct (Conjugated) Bilirubin
* INR / PT
* APTT
* Albumin
* Platelet count (FBC)
* R-Factor auto-calculation
* MELD components

**Specimen:** Serum (Gold top) + Coagulation tube (Blue top)
**Turnaround:** **1 hour**
**Laboratory Notes:**
“Prioritize processing—patient meets criteria for severe DILI.
If INR ≥ 1.5, notify Hepatology Consultant immediately and escalate to level II care.”

**Clinical Rationale:**
“To quantify severity of hepatocellular injury, identify synthetic dysfunction early, and determine risk of progression to acute liver failure.”

---

# **2. Complete ED Acute Hepatitis Panel (STAT)**

**Tests Ordered:**

* HBsAg
* Anti-HBc IgM
* HBV DNA (reflex if HBsAg positive OR if IgM equivocal)
* HAV IgM
* HCV Ab with reflex PCR
* HEV IgM & IgG

**Specimen:** Serum
**Turnaround:** 24–48h for serology, PCR reflex automatically flagged

**Extended Notes to Laboratory:**
“Patient presents with DILI picture but high bilirubin requires exclusion of superimposed acute viral hepatitis.
Reflex HBV DNA and HCV RNA without waiting for GP approval.”

**Clinical Rationale:**
“To rule out acute viral hepatitis coexisting with drug-induced hepatocellular injury.”

---

# **3. Autoimmune Hepatitis Acute Panel (Urgent)**

**Tests Ordered:**

* ANA
* ASMA
* LKM-1
* IgG
* AMA (Anti-Mitochondrial Antibody)

**Priority:** Urgent
**Specimen:** Serum
**Turnaround:** 48–72 hours

**Extended Notes:**
“If IgG > ULN or ANA positive, flag as ‘Potential AIH’ and notify Hepatology.”

---

# **4. Metabolic Liver Injury Screen (Urgent)**

**Tests Ordered:**

* Ferritin
* Transferrin saturation
* TIBC
* Alpha-1-antitrypsin
* Ceruloplasmin (to exclude Wilson’s disease in <45 y/o)

**Specimen:** Serum

**Clinical Rationale:**
“To identify possible metabolic or genetic cofactors worsening acute DILI.”

---

# **5. Abdominal Ultrasound (USG Abdomen Upper) – STAT (1 hour)**

**Order:** USG Abdomen Complete
**Target time:** 1 hour
**Indication:** *Bilirubin 110 μmol/L — exclude obstruction, gallstones, duct dilation, hepatic lesions, biliary obstruction.*

**Radiology Notes:**
“High suspicion for hepatocellular injury, but bilirubin >100 requires urgent exclusion of obstructive pathology.
If bile duct dilation >8 mm → escalate to MRCP.”

---

# **6. MRCP (Conditional Reflex Order)**

**Criteria to trigger reflex:**

* Ultrasound suggests ductal dilation OR
* Suspicion of choledocholithiasis OR
* Cholestasis disproportionate to transaminases

**Priority:** Urgent
**Clinical Rationale:**
“To confirm or exclude mechanical obstruction as cause of intense jaundice.”

---

# **7. NAC IV Infusion — Emergency Order**

**Order:** N-acetylcysteine 3-bag infusion protocol
**Dose:** Weight: 85 kg
**Bag 1:** 150 mg/kg over 1 hour
**Bag 2:** 50 mg/kg over 4 hours
**Bag 3:** 100 mg/kg over 16 hours

**Pharmacy Notes:**
“This is *non-paracetamol DILI*, but NAC indicated due to ALT >1000/12× ULN risk category.
Start immediately—do not delay for lab confirmation.”

**Clinical Rationale:**
“NAC improves outcomes in non-paracetamol DILI by reducing oxidative stress.”

---

# **8. Hepatology Consult – STAT**

**Consult level:** Consultant Hepatologist
**Criteria:**

* Bilirubin >100
* ALT >10× ULN
* AST >350
* Jaundice + severe nausea
* MASLD background

**Clinical Rationale:**
“Requires specialist oversight and risk stratification for acute liver failure.”

---

# **9. Inpatient Admission Order – Hepatology Ward**

**Level:** Urgent
**Destination:** Hepatology Ward (High Monitoring Pathway)
**Reason:**

* Severe DILI
* Need for neuro status monitoring q4h
* INR monitoring daily
* Ongoing NAC therapy

---

# **10. ICE System Safety Flags Applied**

* **Red Flag:** “ACUTE SEVERE DILI — DO NOT DISCHARGE FROM ED.”
* **Auto-alert:**

  * If INR ≥ 1.5 → escalate to Consultant + Critical Care
  * If bilirubin rises by >25% in 12 hours → notify Hepatology
* **Medication Stop Order:**

  * “Methotrexate marked as PERMANENTLY CONTRAINDICATED”
* **Trend Reminder:**

  * New LFT panel automatically scheduled at **+12 hours**

---

# **11. Specimen Collection Instructions**

* Collect **two sets** of serum tubes due to high probability of add-on testing
* Coagulation tube must be processed within 30 minutes
* Mark all specimens “STAT — ACUTE LIVER INJURY”
* Ensure patient receives IV access prior to NAC initiation

---

highlights.text: Severe Acute Hepatocellular DILI with bilirubin >100 μmol/L, ALT 490 U/L
Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI) — SNOMED CT: 240517000
Acute Jaundice — 43959009
Cholestasis — 14140009
“Prioritize processing—patient meets criteria for severe DILI.
“To quantify severity of hepatocellular injury, identify synthetic dysfunction early, and determine risk of progression to acute liver failure.”
“Patient presents with DILI picture but high bilirubin requires exclusion of superimposed acute viral hepatitis.
“To rule out acute viral hepatitis coexisting with drug-induced hepatocellular injury.”
“If IgG > ULN or ANA positive, flag as ‘Potential AIH’ and notify Hepatology.”

* **Trend Reminder:**

  * New LFT panel automatically scheduled at **+12 hours**

props.rawText:
**VueExplore**
**Study Type:** *Ultrasound Abdomen – Emergency / STAT*
**Accession Number:** **USG-240812-001**
**Exam Date & Time:** **2024-08-12 @ 15:02**
**Referring Clinician:** Dr. P. Stevens
**Location:** Emergency Department → Radiology Acute Imaging Bay
**Clinical Indication:**

* Severe acute jaundice
* ALT 490 U/L, AST 350 U/L
* Bilirubin 110 μmol/L
* Suspected **Acute Drug-Induced Liver Injury**
* Need to rule out **obstructive cholestasis** or **biliary obstruction**

---

# **1. Acquisition Details**

* **Modality:** Ultrasound (US) – B-mode + Colour Doppler
* **Scanner:** Philips EPIQ Elite
* **Operator:** Senior Sonographer – S. Patel
* **Views Obtained:**

  * Longitudinal and transverse liver views
  * CBD (common bile duct) measurement
  * Gallbladder (multiple planes)
  * Right kidney
  * Pancreatic head region
  * Portal vein Doppler waveform
* **Exam Quality:** Good; patient tolerated exam despite nausea.

---

# **2. Detailed Radiology Report**

### **Liver**

* Liver size: Normal range
* Parenchymal echotexture: Mildly increased, consistent with **steatosis / MASLD**
* No focal hepatic lesions
* No intrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation
* No free fluid
* No signs of hepatic congestion

### **Gallbladder**

* Normal wall thickness
* No gallstones seen
* No pericholecystic fluid
* Sonographic Murphy’s sign: **Negative**

### **Biliary Tree**

* **Common bile duct (CBD): 5.1 mm (normal)**
* No evidence of obstruction
* No choledocholithiasis
* Normal tapering at the pancreatic head

### **Pancreas**

* Head and proximal body visualised; no mass or dilation of pancreatic duct
* No evidence of obstructive tumour causing cholestasis

### **Portal Vein (Doppler)**

* Normal hepatopetal flow
* Velocity within normal physiological range
* No portal vein thrombosis or flow abnormality

### **Spleen**

* Normal size, no splenomegaly (supports absence of portal hypertension)

### **Kidneys**

* Right kidney normal, no hydronephrosis
* Left kidney partially visualised; normal contour

---

# **3. Radiologist Impression (Final Report)**

**Reported by:** Dr. L. Andrews, Consultant Radiologist
**Report Time:** 2024-08-12 @ 15:25

**Impression:**

1. **No sonographic evidence of biliary obstruction** – CBD normal, no stones, and no intrahepatic duct dilation.
2. Liver shows **mild steatosis**, compatible with known MASLD.
3. No structural cause identified for the acute rise in bilirubin.
4. Findings support a **hepatocellular process**, consistent with **Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI)** rather than obstructive jaundice.
5. No free fluid, no focal liver lesions, and no signs of acute cholecystitis.

---

# **4. VueExplore System Flags**

* **Flag Applied:** *“No mechanical obstruction detected – hepatocellular injury pathway confirmed.”*
* **Auto-Trigger:**

  * “MRCP not indicated unless bilirubin rises beyond 150 μmol/L OR clinical suspicion changes.”
  * Notify Hepatology Consultant of completed imaging.
* **Priority Update:** Imaging urgency downgraded from “STAT” to “Routine Monitoring” after non-obstructive findings.

---

# **5. Recommendations (Auto-generated VueExplore decision block)**

* Continue with **NAC protocol** for severe hepatocellular injury.
* Maintain **Hepatology admission** for close monitoring.
* Repeat ultrasound only if:

  * bilirubin increases
  * cholestasis worsens
  * new abdominal pain develops
* Consider MR elastography or Fibroscan post-recovery (3–6 months).

---

# **6. Audit & Workflow Log**

* 14:58 — ED order placed
* 15:02 — Patient arrived in ultrasound bay
* 15:03 — First image acquired
* 15:25 — Report finalized by Consultant Radiologist
* 15:27 — Report auto-delivered to:

  * ED Clinician Inbox
  * Hepatology On-Call Team
  * Nervecentre alert module
* 15:28 — Care plan updated to: “Proceed with hepatocellular DILI pathway”

highlights.text: Severe acute jaundice
ALT 490 U/L, AST 350 U/L
Bilirubin 110 μmol/L
Suspected **Acute Drug-Induced Liver Injury**
Liver shows **mild steatosis**, compatible with known MASLD.
Findings support a **hepatocellular process**, consistent with **Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI)** rather than obstructive jaundice.
Continue with **NAC protocol** for severe hepatocellular injury.
Maintain **Hepatology admission** for close monitoring.
Care plan updated to: “Proceed with hepatocellular DILI pathway”

description: BigHand Dictation - Dr. Stevens Detailed Clinical Commentary with Highlights

props.rawText:
# **Expanded BigHand Dictation **

**Transcript ID:** GP_SM_0401_WorkupAndCaution_Full (Expanded Version)
**Dictated by:** Dr. P. Stevens, MD, MRCGP
**Length:** ~4 minutes, 45 seconds

---

### **Text (Full Dictation and Clinical Commentary)**

"Dictation for Sarah Miller, date of birth 3rd June 1981, reviewed today in clinic for follow-up of her abnormal liver function tests and to discuss suitability for commencing Methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis.

This was a longer consultation than standard, as the focus today was not only on reviewing numbers but explaining the meaning behind them and ensuring the patient understands the implications for future treatment choices. Sarah presented well, in no acute distress, but her blood tests from last month remain concerning, specifically an ALT of 78 U/L, which is nearly twice the upper limit of normal. The pattern continues to suggest a hepatocellular injury, consistent with the background suspicion of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease MASLD and the long-standing metabolic risk factors we documented previously, including type 2 diabetes, suboptimal glycaemic control, and moderate alcohol intake.

I spent a large portion of this appointment clarifying what this raised ALT means in the context of planning Methotrexate therapy. Methotrexate is a highly effective DMARD, but one with well-established hepatotoxic potential. Its safe use depends entirely on starting it in a liver that is already stable, ideally with completely normal aminotransferases. Even mild instability in LFTs increases risk, but when the baseline ALT is already elevated, as in Sarahâ€™s case, the risk of clinically meaningful injury potentially even severe DILI rises significantly.

I explained in detail the concept of **synergistic hepatotoxicity**   that is, the combined effect of two stressors on the liver producing significantly more damage than either would alone. In her scenario, the â€˜first hitâ€™ is MASLD, which causes chronic low-grade hepatic inflammation. Adding Methotrexate, which itself generates oxidative stress and can create hepatic stellate activation, easily tips the balance into injury. The risk is not theoretical: the evidence base clearly shows that patients with MASLD are more vulnerable to Methotrexate-induced hepatic fibrosis and steatohepatitis.

Because of this, I emphasised to Sarah that we cannot safely proceed with Methotrexate until we definitively exclude other possible chronic liver diseases that would compound the risk further. I explained that viral hepatitis particularly hepatitis B core antibody positivity would fundamentally change monitoring requirements and contraindications. Autoimmune hepatitis must also be excluded because Methotrexate is strongly contraindicated in active AIH, as it can both exacerbate hepatic inflammation and mask clinical symptoms until severe injury has occurred. We therefore agreed to perform the most comprehensive first-line hepatitis and autoimmune screening panel.

I walked Sarah through each test ordered today:
â€¢ Viral serology   HBsAg, hepatitis B core total antibody, hepatitis C antibody, and HEV IgG. I explained that even if surface antigen is negative, a positive core antibody would require modification of future DMARD regimens, and possible prophylaxis, depending on risk.
â€¢ Autoimmune screen   ANA, ASMA, LKM-1 and total IgG, which allow us to reliably detect autoimmune hepatitis patterns.
â€¢ Metabolic screen   ferritin, transferrin saturation and alpha-1-antitrypsin levels, to exclude haemochromatosis and AAT deficiency. Both of these conditions increase susceptibility to DILI and accelerate fibrosis if Methotrexate is used.
â€¢ And a repeat full LFT panel in four weeks, which will help differentiate between a stable chronic mild MASLD pattern versus a dynamic or inflammatory process.

I made it clear to Sarah that if this workup shows viral or autoimmune pathology, Methotrexate would be absolutely contraindicated and we would need to pursue alternative RA management, likely hydroxychloroquine or a biologic agent depending on rheumatology input. If the panel is negative, but ALT remains raised, we will still need to be extremely cautious, as underlying steatohepatitis, even if non-viral and non-autoimmune, carries higher risk.

Sarah was understandably disappointed as she has been hoping for Methotrexate to improve her arthritis symptoms. However, by the end of the discussion she demonstrated good insight into the reasons for delaying treatment. She agreed that patient safety must take precedence, and she verbalised understanding that rushing into therapy could expose her to serious complications.

I also advised Sarah strongly to avoid all NSAID use for now particularly ibuprofen which she normally takes up to five times a week. NSAIDs do carry their own hepatotoxic potential, and we must avoid any additional hepatic irritants until her LFTs settle and the screening is complete.

Finally, I confirmed that she should contact the surgery promptly if she develops any new symptoms such as nausea, jaundice, upper abdominal pain, or dark urine. I documented that a follow-up appointment is scheduled in four weeks to review the full panel and decide on suitability for DMARD initiation.

End of dictation."

highlights.text: specifically an ALT of 78 U/L, which is nearly twice the upper limit of normal.

The pattern continues to suggest a hepatocellular injury, consistent with the background suspicion of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease MASLD and the long-standing metabolic risk factors we documented previously, including type 2 diabetes, suboptimal glycaemic control, and moderate alcohol intake.
Methotrexate is a highly effective DMARD, but one with well-established hepatotoxic potential.

Even mild instability in LFTs increases risk, but when the baseline ALT is already elevated, as in Sarahâ€™s case, the risk of clinically meaningful injury potentially even severe DILI rises significantly.
In her scenario, the first hit is MASLD, which causes chronic low-grade hepatic inflammation.
Adding Methotrexate, which itself generates oxidative stress and can create hepatic stellate activation, easily tips the balance into injury.
The risk is not theoretical: the evidence base clearly shows that patients with MASLD are more vulnerable to Methotrexate-induced hepatic fibrosis and steatohepatitis.
I explained that viral hepatitis particularly hepatitis B core antibody positivity would fundamentally change monitoring requirements and contraindications.

Autoimmune hepatitis must also be excluded because Methotrexate is strongly contraindicated in active AIH, as it can both exacerbate hepatic inflammation and mask clinical symptoms until severe injury has occurred.
â€¢ Viral serology HBsAg, hepatitis B core total antibody, hepatitis C antibody, and HEV IgG.
I explained that even if surface antigen is negative, a positive core antibody would require modification of future DMARD regimens, and possible prophylaxis, depending on risk.
Autoimmune screen ANA, ASMA, LKM-1 and total IgG, which allow us to reliably detect autoimmune hepatitis patterns.
Metabolic screen ferritin, transferrin saturation and alpha-1-antitrypsin levels, to exclude haemochromatosis and AAT deficiency.
Both of these conditions increase susceptibility to DILI and accelerate fibrosis if Methotrexate is used.
And a repeat full LFT panel in four weeks, which will help differentiate between a stable chronic mild MASLD pattern versus a dynamic or inflammatory process.

I made it clear to Sarah that if this workup shows viral or autoimmune pathology, Methotrexate would be absolutely contraindicated and we would need to pursue alternative RA management, likely hydroxychloroquine or a biologic agent depending on rheumatology input.
If the panel is negative, but ALT remains raised, we will still need to be extremely cautious, as underlying steatohepatitis, even if non-viral and non-autoimmune, carries higher risk.
I also advised Sarah strongly to avoid all NSAID use for now particularly ibuprofen which she normally takes up to five times a week.
NSAIDs do carry their own hepatotoxic potential, and we must avoid any additional hepatic irritants until her LFTs settle and the screening is complete.
Finally, I confirmed that she should contact the surgery promptly if she develops any new symptoms such as nausea, jaundice, upper abdominal pain, or dark urine.
